A linguistic corpus is generally constituted of a collection of curated linguistic data from a variety of written and (sometimes) spoken language sources for a multitude of purposes; which is contrary to the datasets of other fields in that they are generally constituted of numerical or semantic data for a specific or limited purpose.
Q4: There are a number of idiosyncrasies that exist even between dialects of the same language which some may feel is necessary to record in isolation (the meaning of the word "biscuit", for instance, is different between American and British English).

Q1: A linguistic corpus is a collection of written or spoken texts used for linguistic analysis, whereas a dataset in other fields generally refers to a collection of structured data used for analysis or machine learning purposes.

Q4: There are so many different corpora, even for the same language like BE or SAE, because each corpus is designed with a specific research question or application in mind, and different types of corpora capture different linguistic features and phenomena.
Q5: Corpora of spontaneous spoken language are relatively rare because they are more difficult and costly to collect and annotate than written language corpora, and also require special ethical considerations and consent from participants.
Q6: The Santa Barbara Corpus of Spoken American English is a good corpus of spoken English because it includes a large and diverse collection of transcribed spontaneous conversations from across the United States, with detailed demographic information about the speakers and annotations for prosody, discourse, and pragmatic features.
Q7: The mix of sources in the Brown Corpus was motivated by the desire to capture a broad range of written genres and language use in American English from the 1960s, including both formal and informal writing styles, and to make the corpus representative of the language as a whole.
Q8: It was a reasonable choice for the Switchboard Corpus not to annotate phenomena like g-drop because the focus was on transcribing speech in a way that was faithful to the speaker's intended meaning and not to impose prescriptive rules of grammar or spelling.

Q1: A linguistic corpus is a large and structured collection of texts used for linguistic analysis, while a dataset in other fields refers to a structured collection of data used for various purposes such as machine learning or statistical analysis.
Q2: As an AI language model, I do not have personal preferences, but I can provide an observation that the Brown Corpus is notable for its balanced representation of different genres and styles of writing, making it a useful resource for linguistic research.
Q3: The creation of the Brown Corpus was motivated by the desire to study the patterns and frequencies of language use in order to improve natural language processing and computational linguistics.
Q4: There are many different corpora for the same language because different corpora serve different purposes and are created with different sampling methods, annotation standards, and text genres, which makes them suitable for various research questions and language processing tasks.
Q5: Corpora of spontaneous spoken language are relatively rare because they are more difficult and expensive to collect, transcribe, and annotate accurately compared to written corpora or scripted spoken corpora.
Q6: The Corpus of Contemporary American English (COCA) is a decent corpus of spoken English because it includes a wide range of spoken genres, transcriptions with time alignment, and a large size that allows for statistically reliable analysis.
Q7: The mix of sources in the Brown Corpus was motivated by the desire to capture a diverse range of written texts from different genres, authors, and time periods to create a representative sample of English language usage in the mid-twentieth century.
Q8: The decision to not represent phenomena like g-drop in the Switchboard Corpus was likely a deliberate choice to focus on features that are more salient in spontaneous spoken language and relevant to specific research questions, rather than trying to capture every possible linguistic variation.
Q9: Project Gutenberg would not be a good basis for analyzing the usage of gonna, as it primarily contains written texts and gonna is a feature of spoken language.
Q10: When searching for papers on and corpora of code switching of bilingual English-Spanish speakers, it becomes apparent that there is a significant amount of research and resources available, reflecting the importance and complexity of code-switching phenomena in multilingual communities.

Q1: While a dataset in other fields refers to a structured collection of data, a linguistic corpus is a specialized dataset that includes natural language texts and annotations used for language analysis and research.
Q2: The Brown Corpus stood out to me in particular because it was one of the first large-scale electronic corpora and played a significant role in the development of computational linguistics.
Q3: The creation of the Brown Corpus was motivated by a desire to analyze and understand the patterns and structures of the English language in a data-driven and quantitative manner.
Q4: There are so many different corpora, even for the same language like BE or SAE, because each corpus may have its own specific goals, genres, sources, and time periods, which cater to the needs and interests of different research communities and NLP applications.
Q5: Corpora of spontaneous spoken language are relatively rare because they are difficult and expensive to collect, transcribe, and annotate accurately, as well as obtaining informed consent and protecting the privacy of the speakers.
Q6: The Spoken British National Corpus is a decent corpus of spoken English because it contains a large and diverse collection of spontaneous speech samples from a wide range of speakers and regions, with detailed annotations for prosody, discourse, and metadata.
Q7: The mix of sources in the Brown Corpus was motivated by the desire to capture a broad range of written genres and language use in American English from the 1960s, including both formal and informal writing styles, and to make the corpus representative of the language as a whole.
Q8: The decision not to include the g-drop phenomenon in the Switchboard Corpus was likely a good choice, as it is a relatively minor feature of spoken language and would have added significant complexity to the transcription process, potentially compromising the quality and consistency of the annotations.
Q9: No, Project Gutenberg would not be a good basis for analyzing the usage of gonna, as it consists entirely of written texts, while gonna is primarily used in spoken language.
